# Introduction

The goal of this chapter is to develop a comprehensive yet parsimonious theory that explains how and why civilian and military actors might be less constrained by the central principles of civil-military relations, which were explained in detail in the previous chapter. The core argument developed in this chapter and tested throughout the remainder of this dissertation, is that changes in the levels of domestic polarization and the prestige of the military ultimately impact the _constraining influence_ of the principles of civilian control of the military, non-partisanship of the military institution, and "non-interference" of the military into certain realms of state politics. Furthermore, this argument claims that when the principles of civil-military relations no longer effectively constrain military and civilian actors, these actors will commit political behaviors that align with recognizable and, to some degree, predictable patterns. In making this argument, this chapter emphasizes _why_ levels in polarization and military prestige alter the constraining influence of civil-military principles and describes the patterns of political behavior to expect when these variables exist at relatively high versus low levels.  

This chapter proceeds in three parts. First, I define the relevant terms that are used throughout this study. Having already established a basic definition and understanding of the origin and meaning of the three foundational principles of American civil-military relations in the previous chapter, I define and trace the developments of the dependent variable, the _political behaviors_ which involve the military institution, and the independent variables, _political polarization_ and _military prestige_. In the second part of this chapter, I explain how the levels of polarization and military prestige impact the constraining influence that the governing principles of civil-military relations have on the propensity of military and civilian actors to engage in various political behaviors that involve the military institution. This second part of the chapter concludes by arguing that a total of four domestic political structures, or environments, are possible, each of which is marked by the presence of relatively low versus high levels of polarization and military prestige, and that each environment is likely to produce certain patterns of political behavior committed by civilian and military actors involving the military institution. Before concluding, the third and final part of the chapter then presents a total of six hypotheses to be tested, analyzed, and explored throughout the remainder of the dissertation.  

# Components of the Theory

A visual representation of the overall theory explained in this chapter and throughout the dissertation is shown below in Figure \@ref(fig:overview) . From left to right, the core argument is that the two independent variables of political polarization and military prestige influence an intervening variable, which is the constraining influence of the fundamental principles or standards of civil-military relations. This core argument further suggests that the overall constraining influence of the fundamental principles of civil-military relations on civilian and military actors impacts the dependent variable, which is certain types and patterns of political behaviors.

## The DV: Political Behaviors

### Military Actors

The dependent variable, the types and patterns of political behaviors which involve the military institution, must be carefully defined. This is especially true because _both_ military and civilian actors can each commit behaviors that challenge or threaten the principles of civil-military relations particularly when examining both military _and_ civilian actors. Yet at the same time, these actors and the particular behaviors they commit are not the same. Elected civilian leaders are inherently political to begin with, and thus, everything they say and do should, at least to some extent, be seen as "political."

This is not the case for military actors, even as scholars have argued that the military will always retain an inherently political flavor that can never be entirely discarded [@brooks_paradoxes_2020; @owens_us_2011; see also @clausewitz_war_1976]. In the scholarly literature, perhaps the key consideration when separating the "political" behaviors of military actors vice "non-political" behaviors that military actors commit is whether the behavior is conducted for the purpose of "influencing" policy outcomes [@brooks_militaries_2009, 213]. While there an almost limitless number of forms such behaviors can take, one helpful framework of these types of behaviors, developed by Risa Brooks (2009), is displayed below in Table \@ref(tab:pol-behav).  

\singlespace

  column_spec(4, width="15em") %>%

\doublespace

Determining which behaviors listed in Table \@ref(tab:pol-behav) are normatively problematic - and when - is a difficult if not impossible endeavor. As Brooks (2009) notes, rendering a normative assessment regarding political activities committed by military officers depends on specific contexts and circumstances, as certain aspects of engaging in these behaviors and activities can also yield positive repercussions [@brooks_militaries_2009]. For instance, when military actors offer commentary to the public, the information they provide can help citizens better understand and process information that is often complex and disconnected from everyday life, particularly if the issue is somewhat technical or complex [@brooks_militaries_2009, 225-231; see also @schultz_democratic_1999]. Furthermore, militaries can alert Congress to potentially destructive decisions an executive may be considering, thus helping the nation avoid undertaking a course of action that will lead to disastrous consequences [@brooks_militaries_2009, 225-231]. While the final decisions ultimately belong to civilian leaders to make, there are nonetheless real and positive benefits of military actors engaging in the political process in overt ways. 

As Brooks notes, however, any benefits of military actors committing political behaviors in the short-term may be outweighed by more deleterious long-term impacts [@brooks_militaries_2009]. When military actors engaging in political activities, they generate  _political costs_ for civilian leaders. These costs vary, but include constraining the options available to civilian leaders, sparking public backlash, and otherwise influencing debate about an impending policy choice away from the true preferences of civilian leaders [@brooks_militaries_2009]. Therefore, and as Brooks (2009) notes, military actors who engage in political activities do so while facing four unique risks. 

A first risk of military actors engaging in political activities is to society's esteem of the military [@brooks_militaries_2009, 234]. Part of the reason the military has maintained its popularity with American society is precisely because it has been seen and viewed as a professional institution that does not routinely engage in inappropriate political activities. A second risk of military leaders committing politically inappropriate acts is that doing so provides civilian leaders with an estimate of a particular military leader's political views, which could jeopardize how civilian leaders consult with that particular but also other military actors [@brooks_militaries_2009, 234]. A third risk which military actors face when engaging in political activities is to the tenets of "military professionalism" laid out by Huntington directly: military actors engaging in political activities renders them less focused on their professional duties of securing the Republic [@brooks_militaries_2009, 235; @huntington_soldier_1957]. A fourth and final risk, one which Brooks argues is the most important to consider, of military actors engaging in appropriate political expression is that doing so could "undermine" civilian leaders and ultimately, the governing principle of civilian control [@brooks_militaries_2009, 235]. Ultimately, Brooks (2009) concludes that the potential benefits of military actors engaging in political activities must be weighed against the potential consequences, and recommends that for the sake of long-term, stable civil-military relations, military actors rarely engage in these and other political activities [@brooks_militaries_2009].

Two other implications are worth noting regarding the activities listed in Table \@ref(tab:pol-behav). First, not _all_ of these listed behaviors are of the qualitative nature such that they generate significant political costs for civilian leaders in every instance. For example, military officers who engage in making "public appeals" can do so, theoretically, without inducing significant political costs. For example, when General Colin Powell wrote a series of op-eds in the early 1990s while serving as the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff in which he articulated his views regarding the use of force, his behavior undoubtedly generated political costs for the candidate, and later, President, Bill Clinton [@powell_opinion_1992; @powell_us_1992]. Engagement in this behavior by a highly respected and prestigious figure likely influenced public opinion and constrained the options available to Clinton as a number of crises erupted across the world in the Balkans, Somalia, Haiti, and Rwanda. Similar levels of costs are not likely generated every time a retired General or Admiral pens an op-ed, or gives an interview to the press. 

Conversely, every instance of a military officer publicly endorsing a political candidate is an inherently political act that by definition, violates the governing principle of non-partisanship, and creates at least some political costs for civilian leaders (i.e., the candidate not endorsed). Regardless of whether the endorsement of a political candidate made by a military actor is effective in persuading the public to change its vote choice [see @golby_military_2012], the endorsement it is impossible for a military officer to make a nonpartisan endorsement of a political candidate. Other behaviors, such as resignation, have sparked considerable debate among scholars of civil-military relations. Some have argued that the public nature of resignation constitutes an inherently political act that should not be practically considered [@golby_beyond_2015], while others have left room for the possibility that in extreme circumstances, resignation is appropriate, regardless of the potential public fallout that may be generated [@dubik_principled_2014; @snider_strategic_2014].

The second implication of Table \@ref(tab:pol-behav) is simply that military actors have a variety of activities at their disposal from which to choose to generate political costs for civilian leaders. The well known collisions that have occurred between the President and various wartime Commanders throughout American history - Lincoln and McClellan, Truman and MacArthur, Obama and McChrystal - perhaps threaten civil-military relations in the most recognizable and public way, but there are other subtle and nuanced means available to the military which also generate political costs that civilian leaders must contend with. 

## Behaviors Committed by Civilians

Civilian leaders can also engage in behaviors that challenge the governing principles previously exposited, though in ways that are different from military actors. To begin with, several of the activities listed in Table \@ref(tab:pol-behav) involve varying degrees of civilian actor acquiescence or involvement. Take, for example, the behavior of military actors endorsing political candidates for office. Most instances of this behavior constitute a figurative two way street in which a candidate asks a military officer to make an endorsement, and a military officer agrees to do so. It was for this reason that, in the aftermath of the Presidential Campaign of 2016, Retired Army General Martin Dempsey, who previously served as the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, published an opinion-editorial piece in _The Washington Post_ in which he criticized both the military officers (retired Army Lieutenant General Mike Flynn, who spoke on behalf of Donald Trump at the Republican convention, and retired Marine Corps General John Allen, who spoke on behalf of Hillary Clinton at the Democratic Convention) who spoke at the respective conventions as well as the civilian leaders who sought their participation. Dempsey stated in the op-ed, "As generals, they have an obligation to uphold our apolitical traditions. They have just made the task of their successors – who continue to serve in uniform and are accountable for our security - more complicated. It was a mistake for them to participate as they did. It was a mistake for our presidential candidates _to ask them to do so_" [@dempsey_military_2016]. 

Whereas the political activities committed by military actors can begin to be considered problematic insofar as they attempt to influence policy outcomes and/or generate political costs for civilian leaders [@brooks_militaries_2009], inappropriate activities at the hands of civilian actors which involve the military institution are those that "politicize" the military. More precisely, the behaviors committed by civilian leaders which "politicize" the military are those that cause the military to either breach or be perceived by the public as breaching the principles of non-partisanship or non-interference (by definition, as was argued in the previous chapter, it is not possible for civilian actors to violate the principle of civilian control). 

Civilian leaders have faced consequences for "politicizing" the military previously. For example, some observers alleged that President George W. Bush's use of General David Petraeus in garnering Congressional support for the "surge" strategy in Iraq politicized the military in unhealthy ways [@coll_generals_2008], while other observers note the increase in retired military generals and admirals who endorse political candidates at conventions [@exum_dangerous_2017] as troubling indicators of the military's politicization. Moreover, under President Donald Trump's tenure in office, charges of politicizing the military were common, perhaps none as vociferous as the reaction to the former President's decision 2018 decision to deploy several thousand troops to the US border with Mexico in response to an impending caravan of migrants from South America. The headline of an op-ed published by several retired Army Colonels in response aptly summarizes the feelings held by many Americans at the time: "Trump's Border Stunt is a Profound Betrayal of Our Military" [@adams_trumps_2018]. 

In summary, military and civilian leaders can engage in certain behaviors which violate the fundamental governing principles of civil-military relations. Military actors have a variety of behaviors at their disposal which, if committed, can generate substantial political costs for civilian leaders. These costs include constraining the policy choices that are available to civilian leaders, generating negative public opinion against civilian leadership, and otherwise presenting options that fail to satisfy the true preferences of civilians [@brooks_militaries_2009]. Alternately, civilians too can engage in political behaviors which politicize the military, leading to an actual or perceived breach of the military institution's non-partisan ethic or a violation of a norm of non-interference by asking or directing the military to do a task that is at best indirectly or, at worst, entirely unrelated to the defense of the nation. 

Having described the dependent variable of study, the political behaviors that can be committed by military and civilian actors which jeopardize the governing principles of civil-military relations, the next task is to describe each of the independent variables: political polarization and military prestige. After defining each of the variables, I trace the respective levels of each variable in contemporary America. 

# IV1 - Political Polarization

The first independent variable of study in this dissertation is political polarization. Polarization is a difficult concept to precisely define. From the perspective of the American politics sub-field, polarization refers to the movement of political thoughts and attitudes away from the political center and towards more ideological extremes [@hare_polarization_2014; @abramowitz_great_2018]. In recent years, the concept of polarization has also risen within the sub field of international relations, particularly as a domestic political feature that impacts various international outcomes, including whether a polarized country can unite to recognize common threats, learn and derive lessons from foreign policy failure, and agree on what role a nation should play on the world stage [@schultz_perils_2017; @myrick_external_2020]. From a broad perspective, one that is more often explored and discussed within the sub-field of political theory, political polarization describes the degree to which a society shares fundamental values, is capable of incorporating divergent worldviews, and the overall degree to which these values unite versus divide a nation [@marsden_twilight_2014; @deneen_why_2018]. In this dissertation, I rely on both the relatively narrower conception of polarization as the divergence of political attitudes away from an ideological center and towards the extreme, as well as a broader conception of the term that recognizes the difficulties which arise when a society can no longer agree upon the fundamental values and worldviews which should govern it. 

## Perspectives on Polarization

Perspectives regarding the _causes_ of political polarization vary. Americanists tend to explain polarization as stemming from differences of opinion over issues pertaining to race and religion [@abramowitz_great_2018], the size and role of government [@sides_two_2015], normative conceptions of personal and national identity [@sides_identity_2018], and other policy issues [@mann_its_2012]. Political theorists and cultural historians, on the other hand, recognize the current polarizing environment as a symptom of a slow yet steady political shift that began in the 1950s, a shift that reflects both the incompatibility of American pluralism to reconcile and "embrace a wide range of both religious and nonreligious viewpoints" [@marsden_twilight_2014, 171] and the inability of liberalism as a political philosophy to deliver on its intended promises of securing individual rights in a manner that is equitable and fair [@deneen_why_2018]. Both explanations of polarization acknowledge that American society is strained because there is no longer a common vision for the values and purposes that should guide and unite society, and that the various perspectives regarding the values that should perform this immensely important task are inherently at odds with each other.   

Scholars note the presence of three characteristics or features that describe the current polarized political landscape. The first feature is that polarization in the US goes far beyond mere political differences between political elites [@mann_its_2012]. In other words, today's polarized landscape extends far beyond the halls of Congress in Washington D.C. While one can argue that everyday citizens may not feel as strongly as elected politicians about every single political issue at stake today, the fact is that the level of disdain held by regular Americans for those who sit on the opposite side of the political spectrum has risen sharply over the past several decades. This phenomenon is known in the American politics literature in particular as "affective polarization" [@iyengar_affect_2012; @iyengar_origins_2019] or "negative partisanship" [@abramowitz_great_2018]. 

A second feature of contemporary polarized politics in the United States is the increasing scope and number of issues that have become included as part of the partisan battleground. Politicians and citizens do not disagree and wage political war over a handful of important issues, but rather, at least seemingly, over everything! Scholars of American politics describe this dynamic of increasing political warfare as "conflict extension" [@layman_party_2002]. As one might expect, the dynamic of "conflict extension," in which every political issue seems to be fought over bitterly, dampens the prospects for bipartisanship and meaningful cooperation across partisan aisles [@layman_activists_2010]. 

A third and final feature of contemporary political polarization in the United States is that issues of identity are increasingly associated with partisanship - to the point that partisan identity itself is an important component of how people view themselves and others [@sides_identity_2018; @robinson_michael_danger_2018]. This feature of polarized politics is perhaps most clearly illustrated by the rise and influence of American "identity politics" in which the normative roles of race, gender, religion, and immigration invoke very strong commitments from individuals on both sides of the partisan aisle [@white_values_2002; @mann_its_2012; @sides_identity_2018]. The prominence of these identity-related issues in politics affirms that these issues are not merely peripheral interests, but rather issues that individual citizens care deeply about and consider to be of fundamental concern. 

## How Bad is Contemporary Polarization?

```{r polar-measurement, include=FALSE, echo=FALSE}
nom_dat <- read_csv("https://voteview.com/static/data/out/members/HSall_members.csv")

south <- c(40:49,51,53)
polar_dat <- nom_dat %>% 
    filter(congress>45 & 
           chamber != "President") %>%
    mutate( 
      year = 2*(congress-1) + 1789,
    ) %>%
    group_by(chamber,congress,year) %>% 
    summarize(
      party.mean.diff.d1 = mean(nominate_dim1[party_code==200],na.rm=T) - 
                           mean(nominate_dim1[party_code==100],na.rm=T),
      prop.moderate.d1 = mean(abs(nominate_dim1)<0.25,na.rm=T),
      prop.moderate.dem.d1 = mean(abs(nominate_dim1[party_code==100])<0.25,na.rm=T),
      prop.moderate.rep.d1 = mean(abs(nominate_dim1[party_code==200])<0.25,na.rm=T),
      overlap = (sum(nominate_dim1[party_code==200] <
                       max(nominate_dim1[party_code==100],na.rm=T),na.rm=T)  +
                 sum(nominate_dim1[party_code==100] >
                       min(nominate_dim1[party_code==200],na.rm=T),na.rm=T))/
                 (sum(!is.na(nominate_dim1[party_code==100]))+
                  sum(!is.na(nominate_dim1[party_code==200]))),
      chamber.mean.d1 = mean(nominate_dim1,na.rm=T),
      chamber.mean.d2 = mean(nominate_dim2,na.rm=T),
      dem.mean.d1 = mean(nominate_dim1[party_code==100],na.rm=T),
      dem.mean.d2 = mean(nominate_dim2[party_code==100],na.rm=T),
      rep.mean.d1 = mean(nominate_dim1[party_code==200],na.rm=T),
      rep.mean.d2 = mean(nominate_dim2[party_code==200],na.rm=T),
      north.rep.mean.d1 = mean(nominate_dim1[party_code==200 & 
                                             !(state_icpsr %in% south)],na.rm=T),    
      north.rep.mean.d2 = mean(nominate_dim2[party_code==200 & 
                                             !(state_icpsr %in% south)],na.rm=T),    
      south.rep.mean.d1 = mean(nominate_dim1[party_code==200 & 
                                              (state_icpsr %in% south)],na.rm=T),    
      south.rep.mean.d2 = mean(nominate_dim2[party_code==200 & 
                                             (state_icpsr %in% south)],na.rm=T),    
      north.dem.mean.d1 = mean(nominate_dim1[party_code==100 & 
                                              !(state_icpsr %in% south)],na.rm=T),    
      north.dem.mean.d2 = mean(nominate_dim2[party_code==100 & 
                                              !(state_icpsr %in% south)],na.rm=T),    
      south.dem.mean.d1 = mean(nominate_dim1[party_code==100 & 
                                              (state_icpsr %in% south)],na.rm=T),    
      south.dem.mean.d2 = mean(nominate_dim2[party_code==100 & 
                                              (state_icpsr %in% south)],na.rm=T),    
    ) 

head(polar_dat)
write_csv(polar_dat,path="voteview_polarization_data.csv")

```


```{r include=FALSE, echo=FALSE}
# Here are up to date versions of the famous party means over time plots for each chamber:
polar_dat_long <- polar_dat %>% gather(score,value,-chamber,-year,-congress)
labels <- c("dem.mean.d1"="DEM",
            "rep.mean.d1"="REP",
            "north.dem.mean.d1"="N. DEM",
            "south.dem.mean.d1"="S. DEM")

polarized_plot <- function(chamb) {
  pdatl <- polar_dat_long %>% 
                filter(chamber==chamb,
                       score %in% c("dem.mean.d1","rep.mean.d1",
                                    "north.dem.mean.d1","south.dem.mean.d1")) %>%
                mutate(party=labels[score]) %>%
                ungroup()
  
  gg <- ggplot(data=pdatl,
               aes(x=year,y=value,group=party,col=party)) +
               scale_x_continuous(expand = c(0.15, 0), 
                                 breaks=seq(1880, max(pdatl$year), by=8)) +
               geom_line() + geom_point(size=0.7) + 
               xlab("Year") + ylab("Liberal-Conservative") + 
               geom_text_repel(data=pdatl %>%
                    filter(year == min(year)),
                  aes(label = party, color = party),
                  size = 3,
                  nudge_x = -8,
                  point.padding = 0.1,
                  segment.color = NA,
                  show.legend = FALSE) +
              theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)) +
              scale_color_manual(values=c("REP"="#c70828","DEM"="#1372ad",
                                         "N. DEM"="#6194F4",
                                         "S. DEM"="#81c4e4"),guide="none") +
              theme_bw()
  gg
}
```
